editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: WILD OATS; OR, THE STROLLING GENTLEMEN.
A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.

div.head: WILD OATS: OR THE STROLLING GENTLEMEN
ACT I.
Scene a Parlour in LADY ARAMANTH'S.
div.stage: Enter SIR GEORGE THUNDER and JOHN DORY.

sp.speaker: SIR GEORGE.
sp.p: I Don't know whoſe houſe we've got into here, John, but I think when he knows me, we may hope for ſome refreſhment. Zounds, I'm as dry as touchwood, and to ſail at the rate of ten knots an hour, ever ſtubble and farrow, from my own houſe, but half a league on this ſide of Goſport, and not to catch theſe deſerters that received the King's bounty and run from their ſhips.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You've ill luck.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Mine, you ſwab.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p:
Ah, you've money and gold, but grace and good fortune have ſhook hands with you theſe nineteen years, for that rogue's trick you play'd
Miſs Amelia, by deceiving her with a ſham marriage, when you paſſd yourſelf for Capt. Sevmor, then putting to ſea, leaving her to break her heart, then marrying another lady.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: But was I not forc'd to that by my father?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Ay, becauſe ſhe had a great fortune—her death was a judgment upon you.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why, you impudent dog-fiſh—upbraid me for running into falſe bay, when you was my pilot, was'n't you—even got me the mock clergyman that performed the ſham marriage with Amelia?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: (Aſide.) You think ſo▪ but I took care to bring a real clergyman.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: But is this a time or place for your lectures?—at home, abroad, at ſea and land, will you ſtill badger me? Mention my Wild Oats again, and—you ſcoundrel, ſince the night my bed-curtains took fire when you were my boatſwain aboard the Eagle, you've got me quite into leading-ſtrings—you ſnatch'd me up on deck, toſs'd me into the ſea to ſave me from being burnt, and I was almoſt drown'd.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You would, but for me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Yes. you dragg'd me out by the ear, like a water dog. Laſt week, becauſe you ſaw the tenth bottle uncork'd, you ruſhed in among my friends, and ran away with me. and the next morning Capt. O'Shanaghan ſends me a challenge, for quitting my chair when he was toaſt-maſter—ſo to ſave me from the head-ach, you'd like to have got my brains blown out.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p:
Oh. very well—be burnt in your bed, and tumble into the water, like a tight fellow as you are, and promiſe yourſelf with ſloe juice, ſee if John cares a piece of mouldy biſcuit about it.
But I thought you had laid yourſelf up in ordinary, retired to live quiet upon your eſtate, and had done with ſea affairs.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: John, a man ſhould forget his own convenience For his country's good,

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: But I wiſh you had'n't made me your valet de chambre—no ſooner was I got on ſhore, after five years daſhing upon rocks, ſhowls, and breakers, then you ſet me upon a hard trotting cart-horſe, that toſs'd me up and down like an old bum-boat in the Bay of Biſcay—and here's nothing to drink after all. Becauſe at home you keep open houſe, you think every body elſe does the ſame.—Holloa, holloa—I'll never ceaſe piping till it calls a drop to wet my whiſſle.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Yes, as John Dory remarks, I fear my trip through life will be attended with heavy ſqualls and foul weathers—When my conduct to poor Amelia comes athwart my mind, it's a hurricane for all that day, and when I turn in at night the ballad of William and Margaret's Ghoſt ſings!—Oh, zounds, the diſmals are coming upon me, and I can't get a cheering glaſs to—Holloa!

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Friend, what would'ſt thou have?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Have—why, I would have grog.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Neither man nor woman of that name abideth here.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Man nor woman—then if you'll bring me Mr. Brandy and Mrs. Water, we'll couple them, and the firſt child probably will be Maſter Grog.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thou doſt ſpeak in parables, which I underſtand not.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Sheer off with your ſanctified poop, and ſend the gentleman of the houſe.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: The owner of this manſion is a maiden, and ſhe approacheth.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Do I behold—it is—how doſt thou do, uncle?

sp.speaker: SIR. GEO.
sp.p: Is it poſſible you can be my neice, Lady Amaranth Thunder?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I'm the daughter of thy deceaſ'd brother, Loftus, called Earl Thunder, but no Lady—my name is Mary.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: But, zounds how is all this—unexpectedly find you in a ſtrange houſe, of which old Sly tells me you're miſtreſs, turn'd quaker, and diſown your title.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thou knoweſt the relation to whoſe care my father left me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Well, I know our couſin, old Dovehouſe, was, a quaker, but did'n't ſuſpect he would have made you one.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Being now gathered to his fathers, he did bequeath unto me his worldly goods, amongſt them this manſion, and the lands around it.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: So thou becomeſt and continue one of the faithful. I'm executor of his will, and by it cannot give thee poſſeſſion of theſe goods but upon theſe conditions.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p:
Tell me of your thee's and thou's, quaker's wills, and manſion, —I ſay, girl, tho' on the death on your father, my eldeſt brother, Loftus Earl-Thunder, from your being a female, his title devolves to his next brother, Robert; tho' as a
woman you can't be an Earl, nor as a woman you can't make laws for your ſex nor for our ſex, yet, as the Daughter of a peer, you are, and by heavens ſhall be, called Lady Amaranth Thunder.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thou makeſt too much noiſe, friend.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Dam'me, call me friend, and I'll bump your blockhead against the capſturn.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Yea, this is a man of danger—I will leave Mary to abide it.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: S'fire, my Lady.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Title is vanity.

sp.speaker: ZACH.
sp.p: Shall thy cook this day dreſs certain birds of the air called woodcocks, and ribs of the oxen likewiſe?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: All—my uncle ſojourneth with me peradventure, and my meal ſhall be a fealt, friend Zachariah.

sp.speaker: ZACH.
sp.p: My tongue ſhall ſay ſo, friend Mary.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Sir George Thunder bids thee remember to call thy miſtreſs Lady Amaranth.

sp.speaker: Zach.
sp.p: Verily, George.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: George, ſirrah.—Tho' a younger brother, the honour of Knighthood was my reward for placing the glorious Britiſh flag over that of a daring enemy—therefore addreſs me—

sp.speaker: ZACH.
sp.p: Yea, good George.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: George and 'Mary—here's levelling!—here's abolition of title with a vengeance! S'blood, in this houſe they think no more of an Engliſh Knight, than if he was a French Duke.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p:
Kinſman, be patient; thou and thy ſon Henry, whom I have not beheld theſe twelve
years, ſhall be welcome to my dwelling. Where now abideth you?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: At the Naval Academy, at Portſmouth.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: May I ſee the young man?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, to make a quaker of him? No, no—but hold—as ſhe is a wealthy heireſs, her marrying my ſon Harry will keep up and preſerve the title in our family (aſide). Would thou be really glad to ſee him. Thou ſhalt Mary—John Dory—Ah, here's my valet de chambre.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Avaſt, old man of war; you muſt inſtantly convoy my ſon from Portſmouth.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Then I muſt firſt convoy him to Portſmouth, for he happens to bo out of dock already.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What wind now?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You muſt know, on our quitting harbour—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Damn your ſea jaw, you marvellous dolphin, give me the contents of your log-book in plain Engliſh.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Why then, the young 'Squire has cut and run.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Got leave to come to you, and the maſter did not find out before yeſterday, that Inſtead of making for home he had ſheer'd off towards London, directly ſent notice to you, and Sam has trac'd us all the way here to bring you the news.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, a boy of mine quit his guns—I'll grapple him—come John.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Order the carriage for mine uncle.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: No, thank'ye, my Lady, let your equipage keep up your own dignity—I've horſes here, but won't knock them up—next village is the channel for the ſtage. My Lady, I'll bring the dog to you by the bowſprit, weigh anchor, croud fail, and after him.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: The man of noiſe doth not tarry—then my ſpirit is glad.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Let Sarah prepare chambers for my kinſman; and hire the maiden for me that thou didſt mention.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I will, for this damſel is paſſing fair, and hath found grace in mine eyes, Mary, as thou art yet a ſtranger in this land, and juſt taken poffeſſion of this eſtate, the law of ſociety doth command thee to be on terms of amity with thy wealthy neighbours.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Yea; but while I entertain the rich, the hearts of the poor ſhall alſo rejoice. I myſelf will now go forth into the adjacent hamlet, and invite all that cometh to good cheer.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Yea; and I will diſtribute among the poor good books.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: And meat and drink too, friend Ephraim, in the fulneſs of plenty—they ſhall join in thankſgiving for thoſe gifts of which I'm unworthy.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: I ſay, Dick Buſkin, harkee, my lad,

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What keeps Rover?

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: I'm ſure I don't know: as you deſired, I paid for our breakfaſt—but the devil's in that fellow, every inn we ſtop at he will always hang behind chattering with the bar-maid or the chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Or any, or no maid—but he's a worthy lad, and I love him better, I think, than my own brother, had I one.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: Oh, but Dick, mind my boy.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Stop, Midg. tho' 'twas my orders, when I ſet out on this ſcamp with the players, the better to conceal my quality, for you before people to treat me as your companion, yet for you at the ſame time ſhould have had diſcretion enough to remember when we are alone that I am your maſter, and ſon to Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: Sir, I aſk your pardon; but by making yourſelf my equal, I've got ſo uſed to familiarity, that I find it curs'd hard to ſhake it off.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, Sir. pray mind that familiarity is all over, my frolic is out, I now throw off the player, and ſhall return directly. My father muſt by this time have heard of my departure from the academy at Portſmouth, and tho' I was deluded away by my rage for acting, 'twas bad of me to give the gay old fellow any cauſe of uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: And, Sir, ſhall I and you never act another ſcene together—ſhall I never again play Sir Harry Wildair for my own benefit, nor ever again have the pleaſure of caneing your honour in the character of Alderman Smuggler?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: In future, act the part of a ſmart coat and hat-bruſher, or I ſhall have the pleaſure of caneing you in the character of one that gives mighty blows. You were a good ſervant, but ſirrah, I find by letting you crack your jokes and ſit in my company, you're grown quite a raſcal.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I was a modeſt well behaved lad, but evil communications corrupt good manners.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Run back and tell Rover to make haſte. To bring you down, I'll clap a livery on you—wear that, or find another maſter.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I don't mind wearing a livery; but when one has ſo long had a halbert, it's damn'd hard to be again put into the rank.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Well, if my father but forgives me, this three months excurſion with the players has ſhew'd me ſome life, and a deviliſh deal of fun—for one circumſtance, I ſhall ever remember it with pleaſure—it's bringing me acquainted with Jack Rover—how long he ſtays—Jack (calls). In this forlorn ſtroller I have diſcovered qualities that honour human nature, and accompliſhments that might grace a prince. My poor friend has often lent me his money; though he ſuppoſed me a poor needy devil, that could never be able to pay him. He ſhan't know who I am till it's in my power to ſerve him; only the rogue always marr'd the grand deſign of my frolic—I had no chance among the pretty women where he was; he had the knack of winning their hearts by his gaiety. Tho' ſo deviliſh pleaſant in his quotations, which on the moment he daſhes in a parody whimſically oppoſite to every occaſion as it happens, I hope he won't find the purſe I've hid in his pocket before we part. I dread the moment—but it's come.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: The briſk lightning I.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Aye, there's the rattle—hurried on by the impetuous flow of his own volatile ſpirits, his life is a rapid ſtream of extravagant whim, and while the ſerious voice of humanity prompts his heart to the beſt actions, his features ſhine in laugh and levity.—

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: I'm the bold Thunder.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'm—if he knew but all— (Aſide.) Keep one ſtanding in the road.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Beg your pardon, my dear Dick, all the fault of—plague on on't, that a man can't ſleep and breakfaſt at an inn, then return to his bed-chamber for his gloves, but there he muſt find chamber-maids thumping feathers and knocking pillows about, and keep one, when one has affairs and buſineſs—upon my ſoul theſe girls' conduct to us is intolerable, the very thought brings blood into my face, and when ever they attempt to ſerve and provoke me ſo—Dam'me but I will—An't I right Dick?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: All in the wrong.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: No matter, that's the univerſal play all round the wreken. But you're ſo conceited becauſe, by this company we're going to join at Wincheſter, you're engaged for high tragedy.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: And you for Ranger's plumes, and Poppington.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Our firſt play is Lear—I was deviliſh imperfect in Edgar to'ther night at Lymington; I muſt look it over (takes out a book) "Away! the foul friend follows me"—Holloa! ſtop a moment, we ſhall have the whole country after us.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: That roſy-fac'd chamber-maid put me in ſuch a paſſion, that by heaven's I walk'd out of the houſe and forgot to pay the bill.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Never mind, Rover, it's paid.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Paid! why neither you nor Midg had money enough.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I tell you 'tis paid.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: You paid—oh! very well, every honeſt fellow ſhould be a flock purſe. Lets puſh on—ten miles to Wincheſter—we ſhall be there by eleven.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Our trunks at the inn are book'd for the Wincheſter coach.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Our hero, Tom Stately, ſlept into the chaiſe with his tragedy-phiz-ha, ha, ha,—rides Bottikin between our Thalia and Melpomene—but I prefer walking to the car of Theſpis. What do you wait for now?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Which is the way?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Then I go there. (point's oppoſite)

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Eh.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: My dear boy, on this ſpot, and at this moment, we muſt part.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Part!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Rover, you wiſh me well.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Well, and ſuppoſe ſo—part.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, part.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: What myſtery and grand—what are you at; do you forget, you, Midg, and I are engag'd to Truncheon the manager, and that the bills are already up with our names to play to night at Wincheſter.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Jack, you and I hope often to meet on the ſtage, in aſſum'd characters, if it's your wiſh we ſhould ever meet again in our real ones of ſincere friends, without aſking whither I go, or my motives for leaving you, when I walk up this road, do you turn down that.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Joke.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'm ſerious—good bye,

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: If you repent your engagement with Truncheon, I'll break off too, and go with you wherever—

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Attempt to follow me, and even our acquaintance ends.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Eh.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Don't think of my reaſons, only that it must be,

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Have I done any thing to Dick Buſkin? leave me.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'm as much concern'd as you.—Good bye.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: I can't even bid adieu, I wont either, if any cauſe could have been given—farewell.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Bleſs my poor fellow—adieu.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Well-good—oh damnation.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE, a VILLAGE, with a COTTAGE and GARDEN.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: WELL, Maſter Ephraim, I may depend on thee, as you quakers never break your word.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I have ſpoken to Mary, and ſhe, at my requeſt, conſenteth to take thy daughter Jane for her handmaid.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: That's hearty—I intended to make a preſent to the perſon that does me ſuch a piece of ſervice, but I ſhant afront you with it.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I am meek and humble, and muſt take affronts.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Then, here's a guinea, Maſter Ephraim.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I expected not this; but there's no harm in a guinea.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: So, I ſhall get my children off my hands. My ſon Sim is robbing me day and night, giving away my corn and what not among the poor; my daughter Jane—when girls have nought to do, this miſchief love creeps into their minds, and then, hey, they're for kicking up their heels.—Sim, ſon Sim.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Yes, feyther.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Call your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Jane, feyther wants you.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Did you call me?

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: I often told you both, but its now ſettled—you muſt go into the world and work for your bread.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Feyther, whatever you think right muſt be ſo; and I am content.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: And I'm ſure, feyther, I'm willing to do any thing you would have me.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: There's ingratitude for you!—when my wife, your mother, died, I brought you up from the ſhell, and now that you're fledg'd, you want to fly off and forſake me.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Why, no, I'm willing to live with you all my days.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: And I'm ſure, feyther, if its your deſire. I'll never part from you.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Here's an unnatural pair—what, you want to hang upon me like a couple of leeches, aye, to ſtrip my branches, and leave me a wither'd hawthorn. See who's yonder (Exit Sim.) Jane, Ephraim Smooth has hired you for Lady Amaranth.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: La, then I ſhall live in the great houſe.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Her Ladyſhip has ſent us all preſents of good books, here, to read a chapter in; it gives a man patience when he is in a paſſion. (gives her a book.)

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Thank her good Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: My being incumbered with you both is the cauſe why old Banks here won't give me his ſiſter.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: That's a pity; if we muſt have a ſtepmother, madam Amelia would make us a very good one—but I wonder how ſhe ſhould refuſe you, feyther, for I'm ſure ſhe thinks you a very portly man, in your ſcarlet coat and new ſcratch.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: However, if Banks ſtill refuſes, I have him in my power, I'll turn them out of their cottage yonder, and the bailiff ſhall procure them a lodging. Here he comes.—

div.p: Well, neighbour Banks, once for all, am I to marry your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: That ſhe beſt knows.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: She ſays ſhe won't.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Then I dare ſay ſhe won't; for tho' a woman, I never knew her to prevaricate.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Then ſhe won't have me. Fine thing that you and ſhe, who's little better than paupers, dare to be ſo damn'd ſaucy.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Why, I confeſs we are poor, but while that's the worſt our enemies can ſay of us, we are content. Exit into garden.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Damn it, I wiſh I had a fair occaſion to quarrel with him, I'd make him content with a devil to him—I'd knock him down, ſend him to goal, and—but—I'll be up with him.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p:
Oh, feyther, here's one Mr. Lamp, a
ringleader of the ſhew-folks, come from Andover, to act in our villages—he wants a barn to play in, if you'll hire him yours.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Surely, boy, I'll never refuſe money; but leaſt he ſhould engage the great room at the inn, run and tell him—ſtop, I'll go myſelf, a ſhort cut through the garden—

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Why, you, or any neighbour is welcome to walk in it, or partake of any thing it produces, but making it a common thoroughfare is—

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Here, ſon, kick down that gate.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Does the lad hear?

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Why, yes, yes.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Does the fool underſtand?

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Dang't I'm but yet young, but if understanding teaches me how to wrong my neighbours. I hope I may never live to years of diſcretion.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: What, you cur, do you diſobey your feyther—burſt open the garden gate, as I command you.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Feyther, he that made both you and the garden gate, commands me not to injure the unfortunate.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Here's an ungracious rogue—then I muſt do it myſelf.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Hold, neighbour—ſmall as the ſpot is, its now my only poſeſſion, and the man ſhall firſt take my life, who ſets his foot in it againſt my will.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: I'm in ſuch a paſſion.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Feyther, if you're in a paſſion, read the book you gave me.

sp.speaker: GAM,
sp.p: Plague, O the wench, but you huſſy I'll,—and you unlucky bud.

div.stage: Gammon goes and ſtands at the door of the houſe.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Zounds, here's a pelting ſhower, and no ſhelter—poor Tom's a-cold. I'm wet through; heres a good promiſing houſe. Going to Gammon's houſe, Gammon prevents his entrance.

sp.speaker: GAMMON.
sp.p: Hold, my lad, can't let folks in till I know who they are; there's a publick-houſe not above half a mile on.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Step in here, young man, my fire is ſmall, but it ſhall cheer you with a hearty welcome.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: The poor cottager and the ſubſtantial farmer. (Kneels) Hear nature, dear goddeſs, hear, if ever you deſign to make his corn-field fertile, change your purpoſe; that from the blighted ears no grains may fall, to fat his ſtubble gooſe. And when to town he drives his hogs (ſo like himſelf) oh let him feel the ſoaking rain; then he may curſe his crimes, to taſte and know how ſharper than the ſerpent's tooth is his.—Dam'me, but I'm ſpouting in the rain all this time. Riſes and enters into Banks's cottage.

sp.speaker: GAMMON.
sp.p: Ah, neighbour, you'll ſoon ſcracth a beggar's head, if you harbour every mad vagrant, this may be one of the footpads that it ſeems have got about the country, but I'll have an execution and ſeize on thy goods this day, my honeſt neighbour.—Eh—the ſun ſtrikes out—quite clear'd up.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: La! Feyther if there is'nt coming down the village.

sp.speaker: GAMMON.
sp.p: Oh! thou huſſy.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Feyther, no time for anger now, here's Lady Amaranth's chariot,—la it ſtops.

sp.speaker: GAMMON.
sp.p: Her Ladyſhip is coming out and walks this way, ſhe may wiſh to reſt herſelf in my houſe—Jane we muſt always make rich folks welcome.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I'll run in and get all the things to rights, but Feyther your cravat and wig is all—

div.stage: Adjuſts Gammon and then exit into the houſe.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Well, maſter Gammon, as you deſired me, I am come to ſerve this copy of a writ, and arreſt maſter Banks, where is he?

sp.speaker: GAMMON.
sp.p: Yes! now I'm determin'd on't—waunts, ſtand aſide, I'll ſpeak to you a-non.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Friend Jane, whom I have taken to be my hand-maid, is thy Daughter,

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: So her mother ſaid, arn't pleaſe your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Ephraim Smooth acquainted me, thou'rt a wealthy yeoman, thy hamlet to-behold with mine eyes, the diſtreſſes of my poor tenants, I wiſh to relieve their wants.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Right, your Ladyſhip, for charity hides a deal of ſin, how good of you to think of the poor, that's so like me, I'm always contriving
how to relieve my neighbours—you muſt lay Banks in priſon to night.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: And if it pleaſe you, will your Ladyſhip enter our humble dwelling and reſt your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Do my Lady, to receive ſo great a Lady from her chariot is an honour, I dreamt not of, tho'—for the hungry and weary-foot travellers my doors are always open, and my morſel ready. Knock, and when he comes out touch him. aſide to Twich.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thou art benevolent, and I will enter thy doors with ſatisfaction.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Twich into Gammon's houſe.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Eh, where's the writ (Knock's at Banks's Door)

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Maſter Twich, what's your buſineſs with me?

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Only a little buſneſs here againſt you.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Me!

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Farmer Gammon has brought a thirty pound bank note of hand of yours

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: I did not think his malice could have ſtretched ſo far; I thought the love he poſſeſs'd for my Siſter might. Why it's true, maſter Twich—to lend our indigent cottagers ſmall ſums, when they where unable to pay their rent, I got a lawyer Quick to procure me the money, and hoped their induſtry would have put it in my power to take up the note before now; however I'll go round and try what they can do, and call on you and ſettle it.
Rov. No, no, that won't do; you muſt go with me.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Old gentleman come quick, or I'll draw another bottle of your currant wine.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: You'd better not make no noiſe, and go with me.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Oh, you're here—rain over—quite fair,—I'll take a ſniff of the open air too—Eh! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: What's that to you?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: What's that to me?—why you're very unmannerly.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Here's a reſcue.

sp.speaker: BANK.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Sir, I'd wiſh you not to bring yourſelf into trouble about me.

sp.speaker: TWICH,
sp.p: Now, ſince you don't know what's civil—if the debt an't paid, to jail you go.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: My kind hoſpitable, good old woman, to jail—what's the ſum you ſcoundrel?

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Better words, or I'll—

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Stop—after me, good or bad, except to tell me what's your demand upon this Gentleman, and I'll give you the greateſt beating, you ever had ſince you commenced raſcal.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Why, maſter, I dont want to quarrel with you becauſe—

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: You'll get nothing by it, do you know, you villian, that I am this moment the greateſt man living.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Who, pray?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: I am the bold Thunder, Sirrah—know that I carry my prize of gold in my coat pocket, tho' Dam'me if I know how it came there (aſide, takes the purſe out.) There's twenty pictures of his Majeſty; therefore, in the Kings Name, I free his legal ſubject, and now who am I?

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Ten pieces ſhort, my maſter; but if you're a houſekeeper, I'll take this and your bail.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Then for bail you muſt have a houſekeeper—what's to be done?—

div.p: Oh, here's old hoſpitality—I know you're a houſekeeper, though your fire-ſide was too warm for me. Look here, ſome rapacious griping raſcal has had this worthy gentleman arreſted—now, a certain good-for-nothing rattling fellow has paid twenty guineas of the ſum, you paſs your word for the other nine, we'll run back into the old gentleman's houſe, and over his currant wine, our firſt toaſt ſhall be, liberty to the honeſt debtor, and confuſion to the hard-hearted creditor.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: I ſhant.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: No—what's your name?

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Gammon. Exit.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Then, dam'me, you're the Hampſhire hog. 'S • eath, what ſhall we do to extricate?—Damn the money.

div.stage: Enter LADY AMARANTH from the Houſe.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: What tumult's this?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: A lady—Ma'am, your moſt obedient humble ſervant—a quaker too—they're generally kind and humane, and that face is a prologue to a play of a thouſand good acts—may-be, ſhe'd help us here (aſide). Ma'am, you muſt know that I know this gentleman—I mean, he got a little behind hand, from bad crops, as every honeſt well-principled man may, and from rain lodging in his corn, and his cattle from murrain and rot—rot the murrain, you underſtand—and then in ſteps I with my—in ſhort, Madam, I'm the moſt out of the way ſtory-teller in the world, when myſelf is the hero of the tale.

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Mr. Banks has been arreſted for thirty pounds, and this gentleman has paid twenty guineas of the ſum.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: My litigious neighbour to expoſe me thus!

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: The young man and maiden within have pictur'd thee as a man of irreproachable morals, tho' unfortunate.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam, he's an honeſt fellow, I've known him above forty years—he's the beſt hand at ſtirring a fire—if you was to taſte his currant wine.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Madam, I never aſpired to an invincible rank in life, yet hirthe •• o to pride and prudence kept me above the reach of pity—but obligation from a ſtranger—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: He really a ſtanger, and attempt to free thee. Friend, thou haſt uſurped a right, which here alone belongeth to me; as I enjoy the bleſſing which theſe lands produce, I own alſo the heart-delighting privilege of diſpenſing thoſe bleſſings to the wretched. Thou madeſt thyſelf my worldly banker, and no caſh of mine in thy hands, but there I ballance my account. (takes a note from a pocket-book.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam, my maſter pays me, our dare I take money from any other hand, without injuring his honour, or diſobeying his command.
Run, run, Orlando, carve on ev'ry tree, The fair, the chaſte, the inexpreſſive ſhe. Exit.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: But, Sir, I inſiſt you'll return him his money—Stop. (going).

sp.speaker: TWICH.
sp.p: Aye, ſtop. (holds Banks)

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Where dwelleth he?

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: I fancy, Ma'am, where he can; I underſtand, from his diſcourſe, that he is on his way to join a company of actors in the next town.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: A profane ſtage player with ſuch a gentle generous heart, yet ſo whimſically wild, like the unconſcious roſe, modeſtly ſtriking from the recollection of its own grace and ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Now, my Ladyſhip, I'm fit to attend your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: This maiden may find out for me whither he goeth (aſide.) Call on my ſteward, and thy legal demands ſhall be ſatisſied. To Twich, who exits.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Here, coachman, drive up my Lady's chariot nearer our door (calling off)

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Friend, be cheerful, thine and thy ſiſter's ſorrows ſhall be but as an April ſhower.

div.stage: Exit Banks into his houſe, Lady A. and Jane.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Hilloa, friend, when does the coach ſet out for London?

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: In about an hour, Sir.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Has the Wincheſter coach ſet out for London?

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: No. Sir. Exit Waiter.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: That's lucky, my trunk is here ſtill—then I will not, ſince I've loſt the fellowſhip of my friend Dick Buſkin, I'll travel no more—I'll try a London audience—who knows but I may get an engagement—this celeſtial lady quaker muſt be rich, and how ridiculous for ſuch a poor dog as I am even to think of her—how Dick would laugh at me, if he knew.I dare ſay by this ſhe has releaſed my kind hoſt from the gripe—I ſhould like to be certain, though.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: You'll dine here, Sir—I'm honeſt Bob Johnſon—kept the ſun theſe twenty year;—excellent dinner on table at two.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yet my love indeed is appetite; I'm as hungry as the ſea, I can digeſt as much.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Hungry as the ſea—then you won't do for my ſhilling ordinary. Sir, there's a very good ordinary at the ſ • racen's head at the end of the town.—ſhou'd'n't have thought, indeed, of hungry foot travellers to eat like—Coming, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I'll not join this company at Wincheſter—no, I'll not ſtay in the country, hopeleſs ever to expect a look, except of ſcorn, from this lady. I wonder if ſhe's found out that I'm a player—I'll take a touch at the London theatre, the public there are candid and generous, and before my merit can have time to create enemies, I'll ſave money, and a fig for the ſultan and ſophy.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Aye, that's he.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: But if I fail, by heavens I'll overwhelm the manager, his empire, and himſelf, in one prodigious ruin.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Ruin! O, Lord!

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: What can you expect elſe, when you follow the young men—I've dogg'd you all the way.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Well, was'n't I ſent.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: O, yes, you were ſent—very likely—who ſent you?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I won't tell it's my Lady, becauſe ſhe bid me not (aſide).

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: I'll keep you from ſhame—A fine life I ſhould have in the pariſh, rare fleering, if a ſiſter of mine ſhould ſtand ſome Sunday at church in a white ſneet—and to all their flouts what could I ſay?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Thus, I ſay—My ſiſter's wrong'd, my ſiſter blows a bell • born as high and noble as the attorney; do her juſtice, or, by the gods, I'll lay a ſcene of Mood ſhall make this hay-mow horrible to beadles.—Say that▪ young Chamont.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p:
Eg • d, I believe its full moon. You go
home to your place, and mind your buſineſs. (to Jane).

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: My Lady will be ſo glad I found him—I don't wonder at it, he's a fine ſpoken man.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Dang it, will you ſtand grinning here at the wild bucks.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Will you be quiet, the gentleman might wiſh to ſend her Ladyſhip a compliment: Arnt pleaſe you, Sir, if it is even a kiſs between you and me, it ſhall go ſafe; for tho' you ſhould give it to me, brother Sim can take it my Lady.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: La, will you go?(puts her off.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: To a nunnery, go—to a nunnery, go, go—I'm curſedly out of ſpirits—but hang ſorrow, I may as well divert myſelf—'tis meat and drink for me to ſee a clown—Shepherd, was't ever at court?

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Then thou art damned.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yes, like an ill-roaſted egg, all on one ſide. Ah, little hoſpitality!

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Eh, where's the ſhewman that wants my barn?—Ah, ſon Sim.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Is he your ſon, young Clodpole—take him to your wheat-ſtacks, and there teach him manners.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Oh, thou art the fellow that would bolt out of the dirty roads into people's houſes—Sim's ſchooling is mightily thrown away, if he has not more manners than thou.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Why, feyther, it is one of the players, he acted Tom Fool in King Larry, t'other night at Lymington—I thought I know'd him, by the face, thof he had a ſtraw hat and a blanket about'n.—Ha, how comical that was you ſaid.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Pellicock ſat upon Jellicock-hill—pillo—loc—loc.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Why, feyther, that's it, he's at it again—feyther, laugh.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, boy, I believe he's no better than he ſhou'd be; the moment I ſaw him, ſays I to myſelf, he's a rogue.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: There thou ſpoke truth to thyſelf for once in thy life.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: I'm glad you confeſs it; but her Ladyſhip ſall have all the vagrants wipt out of the country.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Vagrants, wretch—deſpite overwhelm thee—only ſquint, and by heaven I'll beat thy blown-up body till it rebound like a tennis ball.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Beat my feyther—no, no—thou muſt firſt beat me. (pulls off his coat.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Though love cool, friendſhip fall off, brothers divide, ſubjects rebel, oh, never let the ſacred bond be crack'd betwixt ſon and father. Thou art an boneſt reptile— (to Sim) I never a father's protection knew—never had a father to proteſt.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Ecod, he's not acting now.

div.stage: Enter LANDLORD, with book, pen, and ink.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Landlord, is this Mr. Lamp here?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: I've juſt opened a bottle for him in the other parlour. Exit Gam.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: G'is thy hand—I like thee, I don't know how it is, I think I could loſe my life for him—but muſ'n't let feyther be lickt neither. Exit.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I'll make my entrance on the London ſtage boards in Bays; yes, I ſhall have no competitor againſt me. Egad, its very hard, that a gentleman and an author can't come to teach them, but he muſt break his noiſe, and all that. So the players are gone to dinner. (to Landlord.)

sp.speaker: COACH.
sp.p: Any paſſengers for the fly?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: No ſuch people frequent the ſun, I aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Sun, moon, and ſtars—now mind the eclipſe, Mr. Johnſon.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: I heard nothing of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: Sir, twno gentlemen in the parlour wiſhes to ſpeak with you. (to Rov.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I attend them with all reſpect and duty.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Sir, you go in the ſtage; as we book the paſſengers, what name?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I'm the bold Thunder. Exit.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Mr.Thunder.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I want two places in the ſtage coach, becauſe I and another gentleman are going a journey.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Juſt two vacant—what name?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Avaſt, I go upon deck, but let me ſee who is my maſter's meſſmates in the cabbin. (reads) Capt. M'Clallough, Councellor Flaherghan, Miſs Goſling, Mr. Thunder—what's this—ſpeak, man, is there any perſon of that name going?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Book'd him this moment.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: If our voyage ſhould be at an end before we begin; if this Mr. Thunder ſhould be my maſter's ſon—what ſort of a gentleman is he?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: An odd ſort of a gentleman—I ſuſpect he's one of the players.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: True, Sam ſaid 'twas ſome of the players people forced him from Portſmouth ſchool—it muſt be the 'Squire—ſhew me where he's moor'd, my old purſer. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: TRAP.
sp.p: This ſame old Gammon ſeems a ſurly ſpark.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: No matter; his barn will hold full thirty pounds, and if we can but engage this young fellow, this Rover, he'll cram it every night he plays—he's certainly a very good actor. Now, Trap, you muſt enquire out a good carpenter, and be briſk about the building. I thihk we ſhall have ſmart buſineſs, as we ſtand ſo well for women too—Oh, here he comes.

sp.speaker: TRAP.
sp.p: Knap him on any terms.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient—the waiter told me—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Pra • , ſit down, good Sir. Sir, to our better acquaintance. (drinks)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Hav'n't a doubt, Sir.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Only ſuffer me to put up your name to play with us ſix nights, and twelve gu neas are yours.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I thank you; I muſt confeſs your offer is liberal, but my friends have flattered me into a ſort of opinion, that encourages me to take a touch at the capital.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Sir, a London theatre is very dangerous ground.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Why, I may fail, and gods may groan, and lad • es cry, the aukward creature; but ſhould I t • p my part thus, ſhall not gods applaud, and ladies ſigh, the charming fellow, and the managers take me by the hand, and treaſurers ſmile upon me, as they count the ſhining guineas.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Aye, ſuppoſe the contrary, I have a certain friend here in my coat pocket—(feels for it)—Zounds, where is it—Oh, the devil, I gave it to diſcharge my kind hoſt. Going to London, and not maſter of five ſhillings (aſide). Well, Sir, if you'll make it twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Sir, I engage with you; call a rchearſal when and where you pleaſe, and I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Sir, I'll ſtep for the caſt book, and you ſhall chooſe your characters.

sp.speaker: TRAP.
sp.p: And I'll write the play-bill directly.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Since I muſt remain here ſome time, and hav'n't the moſt diſtant hope of ever ſpeaking to this goddeſs again, I wiſh I had enquired her name, that I might know how to keep out of her way.

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: There's the gentleman.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Very well. (Exit Land.) What cheer, maſter 'Squire.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What cheer, eh, my hearty.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: The very face of his father—And ar'n't you aſham'd of yourſelf?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Why, yes, I am ſometimes.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Do you know, if I had you at the gangway, I'd give you a neater dozen than ever you got from your ſchool-maſter's cat-o-nine-tails.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You wou'dn't, ſure.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I would, ſure.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Indeed, pleaſant enough. Who is this genius?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I've diſpatch'd a ſhallop to tell Lady Amaranth you're here.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You hav'n't.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Now who the devil's this Lady Amaranth?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I expect her chariot every moment, and when it comes, you'll get into it, and I'll ſet you down genteelly at her houſe, then I'll have obeyed my orders, and hope your father will be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My father—who is he, pray?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Pſha, leave off your fun, and prepare to aſk his pardon.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—my worthy friend, you're quite wrong in this affair;—upon my word, I'm not the perſon you take me for. (going.)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You don't go, tho' you've got your name down in the ſtage-coach book, Mr. Thunder.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Mr. Thunder—ſtage-coach book—this muſt be ſome curious miſtake—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Oh, my lad, your father, Sir George, will ſoon change your note.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Will he—he muſt firſt give me one. Sir George—then my father's a Knight, it ſeems—very good, faith—ha, ha, ha. I'm not the gentleman you think, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I ought not to think you any gentleman, for giving your honour in a falſe word.

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: Her Ladyſhip's carriage is at the door, and I fancy, Sir, it's you the coachman wants. (to John).

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, it's me (exit Waiter). I attend your honour.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: The choice is made, and I've my Ranger's dreſs in my trank, Couſin of Buckingham, thou ſage grave man.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Since you will buckle fortune on my back, to bear the burthen whether I will or no, I muſt have patience to endure the load; but if black ſcandal, or foul-fac'd—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Black, foul-fac'd—dam'me, my face was as fair as yours before I went to ſea.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Your mere enforcement ſhall acquaintance me.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Man, dont ſtand preaching parſon Palmer, come to the chariot.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Aye, to the chariot bear me—Bucephalus among the billows. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: THO' thou haſt ſettled that diſtreſſed gentleman's debts, let his ſiſter come unto me, and remit a quarter's rent to all my tenants.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: As thou biddeſt it, I have diſcharged from the pound, the widow's cattle; but ſhall I let the lawſuit drop againſt the farmer's ſon, who did ſhoot the pheaſant?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Yea; but inſtantly turn from my ſervice the gamekeeper's man that did kill the fawn while it was eating from his hand—we ſhould hate guile, tho' we love veniſon.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Since the death of old Dovehonſe (who, though one of the faithful, was an active man) this part of the country is infeſted with covetous men, called rabbers; and I have, in thy name, ſaid unto the people, whoever apprehendeth one of theſe, I will reward, yea, with thirty pieces of gold. (knockiug without.) That beating of one braſs againſt another at thy door, proclaimeth the approach of vanity, whoſe heart ſwelleth at an empty ſound. Exit.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p:
But my heart is poſſeſsed with the idea of that wandering youth, whoſe benevolence induced him to part with, perhaps his all, to free the unhappy debtor. His perſon is amiable, his addreſſes (according
to the worldly modes) formed to pleaſure and to delight—but he's poor—is that a crime?—perhaps meanly born—but one good action is an illuſtrious pedigree.—I feel I love him, and in that word are birth, fame, and riches.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, my Lady, an't please you.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Did'ſt thou find the young man, that I may return him the money he paid for my tenant?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I found him, Ma'am, and I found him, and he talked of what he ſaid.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: He ſaid, Ma'am, and ſays he—I'll be hang'd, Ma'am, if he did'n't talk about ruin, now I think of that—but if he had'n't gone to London in the ſtage coach—

sp.speaker: LADY L.
sp.p: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Oh, my Lady, mayhap John Dory is not the man to be ſent after young gentlemen that ſcamper from ſchool, and run about the country a play acting. Pray walk up ſtairs, Maſter Thunder.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Haſt thou brought my kinſman hither?

sp.speaker: JOHN,
sp.p: Well then, I ha'n't—will you only walk up, if you pleaſe, Maſter Harry?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Will you walk up, if you pleaſe, Maſter Harry?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Frienaſhip requireth, yet I'm not diſpoſed to communicate with company.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Oh, bleſs me, Ma'am, if it is'n't—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Hamlet, the Dane—thus far into the bowels of the land have we march'd on—John, the bloody devouring beat.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: He call'd me bull in the coach.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: This Lady Amaranth—by heavens, the very angel quaker.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: The generous youth, my couſin Harry.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: He's for you, make the moſt of him.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Oh, how happy my Lady is—he looks ſo charming now he's fine.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Harkee—ſhe's as rich as an India-man, and I tell you, your father wiſhes you would grapple her by the heart. There's an engagement between theſe two veſſels but little Cupid's the only man that's to take'em in tow, ſo come. (to Jane.)

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Ma'am, a'n't I to wait on you?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, my laſs, you're to wait on me.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Wait on you!—lack-a-day, am I?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: By this, Sir George is come to the inn. Without letting the younker know, I'll bring him here, and ſurpriſe both father and ſon with a joyful meeting (aſide). Now court her, you mad devil (to Rover). Come, now uſher me down like a lady. (to Jane).

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Yes, there's love between them, I ſee it in their eyes—bleſs the dear couple—this way, Mr. Sailor gentleman. Exeunt Jane and John.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: By heavens, a moſt delectable woman.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Couſin, when I ſaw thee in the village free the ſheep from the wolf, why did'ſt not tell me thou wer't ſon to my uncle, Sir George?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Becauſe, my Lady, I did not know it myſelf.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Why would'ſt thou vex thy father, and quit thy ſchool?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: A truent diſpoſition—good my Lady brought me from Whittemberg.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thy father deſigns thee for his dangerous profeſſion—but is thy inclination turned to the voice of trumpets and ſounds of mighty ſlaughter?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p:
Why, Ma am, as for old Boreas, my dad▪ when the blaſt of war blows in his ears, he's a tyger in his fierce reſentment; but, for me, I think it a pity
—ſo it is—that villainous ſaltpetre ſhould be digg'd out of the bowels of the harmleſs earth, which many a good tall fellow hath deſtroy'd, with wound, and guns, and drums—Heaven ſave the mark!

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Indeed thou art tall, my couſin and grown of comely ſtature—our families have long been ſeparated.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: They have, ſince Adam, I believe (aſide)—then, lady, let that ſweet bud of love now ripen to a beauteous f • ower.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Love!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Excellent wench—perdition catch my ſoul—but I do leve thee; and when I love thee not—Chaos is come again.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thou art of a happy diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: If I were now to die, it were to be happy!—Let our ſenſes dance in concert to the joyful minutes, and this, and this, the only diſcord make (embracing).

div.stage: Enter JANE, with cake and wine.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Ma'am, an't pleaſe you, Mr. Zachariah bid me—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Why you fancy yourſelf Cardinal Woolſey in this family.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: No, Sir, I'm not Cardinal Woolſey, I'm only my Lady's maid here.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: A bowl of cream for your Catholic Majeſty's.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Cream! no, Sir;—that wine and water.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You get no water—take the wine, great Potentate.

div.stage: (Gives Lady A. a glaſs, and drinks).

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Madam, my father begs leave—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Go, go, thou ſhallow Pomona. Exit Jane.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Eh! Zouns, my Manager!

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p:
I hope her Ladyſhip hav'n't found out 'twas I had Banks arreſted (aſide). Wou • d your Ladyſhip give leave for this honeſt man and comrades to act a
few plays in the town, cauſe I have let 'em my barn—'twill be ſome little help to me, my Lady.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My Lady, I underſtand theſe affairs, leave me to ſettle them.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: True, theſe are deluſions, as a woman, I underſtand not—but by my couſin's advice I will abide—aſk his conſent.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: So, I muſt pay my reſpects to the young 'Squire (aſide). An't pleaſe your honour, if a poor man, like me (bows) dare offer his humble duty.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Can'ſt thou bow to a vagrant, Eh, little Hoſpitality, Exit Gammon.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Pleaſe your honour, if I may preſume to hope, you'll be graciouſly pleaſed to take our little ſquadron under your honour's protection.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou, Henry.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Aye, where's Henry?—true—that's me—ſtrange I ſhould always forget my name, and not half an hour ago I was chriſten'd (aſide). Hark ye, do you play yourſelf, fellow?

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and I've juſt now engaged a new actor, one Mr. Rover—ſuch an actor.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: If ſuch it your beſt actor, you ſha'nt have my permiſſion—my dear Madam, the damndeſt fellow in the world—get alone out of the town, or▪ dam'me, I ll have you all, man, woman, and child, rag and fiddle- •• ick, clap'd into the whirligig.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Good man, abide not here.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What, you ſcoundrel!—now if this new actor you brag of, that crack of your company, was any thing like a gentleman—

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Why ſince it is'n't—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: It is, my dear friend, if I was really the poor ſtrolling dog you thought me, I ſhould tread your four boards, and crow the cock of your barndoor fowl; but, as Fate has ordain'd, I'm a gentleman, and ſon to Sir—what the devil's my father's name (aſide).—You muſt be content to murder Shakeſpeare, without making me an accomplice.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p:
But, my moſt gentle Sir, I and my treaſurer, Trap, have trumpeted your fame ten miles
round the country—the bills are poſted, the candles bought, the ſtage built, the fiddlers engag'd—all on the tip-toe of expectation—we ſhould have to-morrow night an overflow—ay, thirty pounds, dear worthy Sir; you would not go to ruin a whole community and their families, that now depends on the exertion of your brilliant talents.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I never was uniform but in one maxim, that is, though I do little good, to hurt nobody but myſelf.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Since thou haſt promiſed, much as I prize the adherance to the cuſtoms in which I was brought up, thou ſhalt not fully thy honour, by a breach of thy word; for truth is more ſhining than beaten gold—play, if it can bring good to theſe people.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Shall I?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: This falleth out well, for I have bidden all the gentry round unto my houſe warning, and theſe pleaſentries may afford them innocent and chearful entertainment.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: True, my Lady, your gueſts an't Quakers, though you are; and when we aſk people to our houſe we ſtudy to pleaſe them, not ourſelves; but if you do furbiſh up a play or two, the Muſes ſhan't honour that churliſh fellow's barn.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Barn! no, that gallery ſhall be thy theatre; and, in ſpite of the grave doctrine of Ephraim Smooth, my friends and I will behold and rejoice in thy pranks, my pleaſant couſin.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My kind, my charming Lady!—Hey!—brighten up bully Lamp, Carpenters, Taylors, Managers, diſtribute your box tickets for my Lady's gallery—come, gentle couſin, the actors are at hand, and by their ſhew you ſhall know all that you are like to know. Exit Lamp. Exeunt Lady and Rover.

div.stage: SCENE, AN APARTMENT IN AN INN.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
Though I went back to Portſmouth
Academy with a contrite heart to continue my ſtudies, yet, from my father's angry letter, I dread the woeful ſtorm at our firſt meeting. I fancy the people at the inn don't recollect me; it reminds me of my pleaſant friend, poor Jack Rover; I wonder where he is now.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: And brings to my mind a certain ſtrolling acquaintance of mine, poor Dick Buſkin.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Then I deſire, Sir, you'll turn Dick Buſkin out of your head.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: Can't, Sir, the dear, good-natur'd, wicked ſon of—I beg your honour's pardon.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Midg, you muſt, ſoon as I'm dreſt, ſtep out and enquire whoſe houſe my father is at—I didn't think he had any acquaintance in this part of the country; found what humour he's in, and how the land lies, before I venture into his preſence.

sp.speaker: WAIT.
sp.p: Sir, the room is ready for you to dreſs.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I ſhall only throw off my boots, and you'll ſhake a little powder in my hair.

sp.speaker: MIDG.
sp.p: Then, hey puff, I ſhoulder my curling-irons.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I can hear nothing of theſe deſerters—by my firſt intelligence, they'll not venture up to London; they muſt ſtill be lurking about the country—Landlords have any ſuſpicious looking perſon put in at your houſe?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, now and then.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What do you do with them?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Why, Sir, when a man calls for liquor, that I think has got no money, I make him pay beforehand.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p:
Damn your liquor, you ſelf-intereſted porpoiſe, chattering about your own private affairs, when public good, or fear of general calamity, ſhould be the only compaſs; theſe fellows I am in purſuit of, run from their ſhips; and if our navy is unmanned,
what becomes of you and your houſe, you dunghill cormorant?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: This is a very abuſive ſort of a Gentleman, but he has a full pocket, or he wou'd not be ſo ſaucy (aſide). Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR GEORGE.
sp.p: This raſcal, I believe, does not know I'm Sir George Thunder—wind, ſtill variable, blows my affairs athwart each other, to not know what's become of my runagate ſon Harry—and when my Lady niece, ſqueezing up the plumage of our illuſtrious family in her little mean Quaker's bonnet—I muſt to town after—Shood! when I catch my ſon Harry—Oh, here's John Dory.

div.p: Have you taken the places in the London coach for me?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Ha!—Hey, your honour, is that yourſelf?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: No, I'm beſides myſelfmdash;where's my ſon?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: What's o'clock?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why do you talk of clocks or time-pieces?—all Glaſs's reckoning and log-line are run wild with me.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: If it's two, your ſon is this moment walking with Lady Amaranth in her garden.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: With Lady Amaranth?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: If half after, the're caſt anchor to reſt themſelves among the poſies; if three, they're got up again; if four, they're picking a bit of cram'd fowl; and if half after, they're picking their teeth, and cracking walnuts over a bottle of calcavella.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: My ſon!—my dear friend, where did you find him?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I found him where he was, and I found him where he is.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What! and he come to Lady Amaranth's?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p:
No, I brought him there from this houſe, in her carriage—I won't tell him Maſter Harry went
among the players, or he'd never forgive him (aſide).—Oh, ſuch a merry, civil, crazy, crack-brain'd—the very picture of your honour.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, he's in high ſpirits—ha, ha, ha—the dog—I hope he had diſcretion enough tho' to throw a little gravity over his mad humour, before his prudent couſin.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: He threw himſelf upon his knees before her, and that did quite as well.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Made love to her already!—ha, ha, ha,—oh the impudent, cunning villain!—what, and may be he—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Indeed he did give her a ſmack.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Indeed—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Oh, he threw his arms about her as eager, as I wou'd to catch a falling decanter of Madeira.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Huzza, victoria!—here will be a juncture of two bouncing eſtates—but confound the money!—John, you ſhall have a bowl for a jolly boat of ſwim in. Roll in a puncheon of rum, a hogſhead of ſugar, ſhake an orchard of oranges, and let the landlord drain his fiſh-pond yonder—a bumper, a bumper, &c. (ſings).

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Then, my good Maſter, Sir George, I'll order a bowl, ſince you're in the humour for it.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: And ſo the wild rogue is this inſtant rattling up her prim Ladyſhip? Eh, is'n't this he? Left her already!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I muſt have left my cane in this room.—Eh, my father!

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Juſt half after four: why, Harry, you've made great haſte in cracking your walnuts.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes; he has heard of my frolics with the players. (Aſide.) Dear father, if you'll but forgive me—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why, indeed, you have acted very bad.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Sir, it ſhould be conſidered I was but a no vice.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: However, I ſhall think of nothing now but your Benefit.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Very odd his approving of— (Aſide.) I thank you, Sir; but if it's agreeable to you, I have done with Benefits.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: If I was not the beſt of fathers, you might indeed hope none from me; but no matter if you can but get the Fair Quaker—

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Or the Humours of the Navy. Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What! How dare you reflect on the Humours of the Navy? The navy has very good humours, or I'd never ſee your dog's face again, you villain! But I'm cool—Eh, boy, a ſnug eaſy chariot.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'll order it; deſire my father's carriage to draw up.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Mine, you rogue, I've none; I mean Lady Amaranth's.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Lady Amaranth's chariot.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What are you at? I mean that you left this life in.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Sir, I left this houſe on foot.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, with John Dory?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: No, Sir; with Jack Rover.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why John has been a Rover to be ſure; but now he is ſettled: I've made him my Valet de Chambre.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Made him your Valet! Why, Sir, where did you meet with him?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Zounds! I meet him abroad and meet him on ſhore—in the cabin and ſteerage—gallery and forecaſtle.—He ſail'd round the world with me.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Strange this: I underſtood he had been in the Eaſt Indies, but he never told me he knew you; but, indeed, he only knew me by the name of Dick Buſkin.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Then how came he to bring you to Lady Amaranth's?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Bring me where?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Anſwer me; a'n't you now come from her Ladyſhip's?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Ha, this is a lie of John's to enhance his own ſervices. Then you have not been there?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I don't know where you mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Yes, it's all a brag of John's; but I'll—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: The rum and ſugar is ready; but as for the fiſh-pond—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'll kick you into it, you thirſty old grampus.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Will you? Then I'll make a comical roaſted orange.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: How dare you ſay you brought my ſon to Lady Amaranth's?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: And who ſays I did'n't?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: He that beſt knows only, Dick Buſkin here.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Buckſkin mus'n't ſhoot off great guns for his amuſement.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: There, what do you ſay to that?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I ſay 'tis falſe.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Falſe!—ſhiver my hulk, Mr. Buckſkin, if you were a lyon's ſkin I'd curry your hide for this.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: No, no—John's honeſt—I ſee through it now—the puppy has ſeen her; perhaps he has the impudence not to like her—and ſo blow up this confuſion and perplexity only to break off a marriage.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What does he mean—I'll aſſure you—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Damn your aſſurance, you ungrateful, diſobedient—but I'll not part with you till I confront you with Lady Amaranth herſelf, face to face; and if I prove you have been deceiving me, I'll launch you into the wide ocean of life, without a rudder, compaſs, grog, or tobacco. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: THE fanciful flights of my pleaſant couſin enchants my ſenſes; this book he gave me to read containeth good morals, the man Shakeſpear, that did write it, they call immortal: he muſt indeed have been filled with divine ſpirit. I underſtand, from my couſin, the origin of plays were religious myſteries; that, freed from the ſuperſtition of early, and groſsneſs of latter times, the ſtage is now become the vehicle of delight and morality; if ſo, to hear a good play is taking the wholeſome draught of precept from a golden cup, emboſſ'd with gems, yet giving my countenance to have one in my houſe, and even to act in it myſelf, prove the aſcendency my dear Harry has over my heart. Ephraim Smooth is much ſcandalized at theſe doings.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: This manſion is now become the tabernacle of Baal.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Then abide not in it.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: 'Tis full of the wicked ones.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Stay not among the wicked ones.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I muſt ſhut my ears. (loud laugh)

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: And thy mouth alſo, good Ephraim; I have bidden my couſin Harry to my houſe, and will not ſet bounds to his mirth, to gratify thy ſpleen, and ſhew my own inhoſpitality.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p:
Why doſt thou ſuffer him to put into the hands of thy ſervants books of tragedies, and books
of comedies, preludes, and interludes—yea, all ludes; my ſpirit doth wax wrath. I ſay unto thee, a playhouſe is a ſchool for the old dragon, and a play-book the primmer of Belzebub.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: This is one; mark. (reads) "Not the King's crown, nor the deputed ſword, the marſhal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe, becometh them with one half ſo good a grace as mercy doth. Oh! think on that, and mercy then will breathe within your lives like men new made." Doth Belzebub ſpeak ſuch words?

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thy kinſman hath made all thy ſervants actors.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: To act well is good ſervice.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Here cometh the damſel, for whom my heart yearneth.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am! his young honour, the 'Squire, ſays the play's to be As You Like It.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I like it not.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: He's given me my character; I am to be Miſs Audrey, and be ther Sim's to be William of the Foreſt, as it were; but how am I to get my part by heart?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: By often reading it.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Well, I don't know but that's as good as any other.—I muſt ſtudy my part—the Gods give us joy. Exit.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thy maidens ſkip like young kids.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Then, do thou go ſkip along with them.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Mary, thou ſhould' • t be obey'd in thine own houſe, and I will do thy bidden.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Ah, thou hypocrite, to obey is eaſy, when the heart commands.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p:
Oh, my charming couſin, how agre you and Roſalind? Are you almoſt perfect? What old Clytus, why you're like any angry friend brok
in amongſt the laughing Gods; come, come, I'll have nothing here but quips, and cranks, and wreathed ſmiles

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: He ſays we muſt not have this amuſement.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: But I have a voice potential, double as the Duke's, and I ſay we muſt.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Nay.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yea, by Jupiter I ſwear—Aye. (fiddle without.)

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: The man of ſin rubbeth the hair of the horſe to the bowels of the cat.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: Now, if agreeable to your Ladyſhip, we'll go over your ſong.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I'm content.

div.stage: [Lamp begins to play, Ephraim puſhes his elbow, which puts him out of tune—plays again—Eph. joggs as before.]

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: What, Sir, do you mean?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Now do, my good friend, be quiet.—Come, begin.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Friend, this is a land of liberty, and I've as much right to move my elbows, as thou haſt thine. (Rover puſhes him) Why doſt thou do ſo, friend.

sp.speaker: ROV,
sp.p: Friend, this is a land of liberty, and I have as much right to move my elbows as thou haſt to move thine. (puſhes him off.) A fanatical puppy.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: But, Harry, do you people of faſhion act theſe folies themſelves?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Aye, and ſcramble for the top parts as eager as for ſtars, ribbands, place, or penſion. Lamp, decorate the ſeats out ſmart and theatrical, and drill the servants that I have given the ſmall parts.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p:
I wiſh'd for ſome entertainment, in which people now take delight, to pleaſe thoſe I have invited, but will convert thoſe folies into a charitable purpoſe: Tickets of this play ſhall be delivered to my friends gratis, but money to their amount I will, from
my own purſe (after rewarding the aſſiſtants) diſtribute among the indigent of the village; thus, while we amuſe our friends, and perhaps pleaſe ourſelves, we ſhall make the poor happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: An angel!—If Sir George does'n't ſoon arrive to blow me, I may, I think, marry her angelic Ladyship—but will that be honeſt?—ſhe's nobly born—tho' I ſuſpect I had anceſtors too, if I knew who they were.—I entered this houſe the pooreſt wight in England, and what muſt ſhe imagine when I'm diſcovered?—that I'm a ſcoundrel; and conſequently, though I ſhould poſſeſs her hand and fortune, inſtead of loving, ſhe'll deſpiſe me. (ſits) I want a friend now to conſult—deceive her I will not—poor Dick Buſkin wants money more than myſelf, yet this is a meaſure I'm ſure he'd ſcorn—no, no, I must not.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Now, I hope my paſſionate father will be convinced that this is the firſt time I was ever under this roof. What beau is here?—aſtoniſhing! my old ſtrolling friend. (ſits down unperceived)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I don't know what to do.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Nor what to ſay.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Dick Buſkin, ha, ha, ha,—my dear fellow—think of the devil, and—I was juſt thinking of you—'pon my ſoul, Dick, I am happy to ſee you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: But, Jack, how the devil have you found me out?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Found you, I'm ſure I wonder how the deuce you found me out—oh, the news of my intended play has brought you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: He does not as yet know who I am, ſo I'll carry it on. (aſide.) Then you have broke your engagement with Truncheon, at Wincheſter?—figuring away in your ſtage cloaths too, really.—Tell me what you are at here, Jack?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Will you be quiet with your Jacking, I'm now 'Squire Harry.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I've been preſs'd into this ſervice by an old man of war, who found me at the inn, and inſiſted I'm ſon to Sir George Thunder. In that character, I flatter myſelf, I have won the heart of the charming lady of this houſe.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Now the myſtery is out— (aſide)—then it's my friend Jack has been brought here for me.—Do you know the young gentleman they take you for?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Not I; but I flatter myſelf he is honoured in his repreſentative.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Jack, you're a tight fellow.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Now I can put ſome pounds in your pocket—you ſhall be employed—we're getting up As You Like It—let's ſee in the caſt, have I a part for you—egad, I'll take Touchſtone from Lamp, you ſhall have it, my boy—I'd reſign Orlando to you with any other Roſalind, but the lady of the manſion plays it herſelf.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: The very lady my father intended for me. (aſide) Do you love her, Jack?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: To diſtraction—but I'll not have her.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: No—why?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: She thinks me a gentleman, and I'll not convince her I'm a raſcal; I'll go on with our play, as the produce is appropriated to a good purpoſe, then lay down my 'Squireſhip, bid adieu to my heavenly Roſalind, and exit for ever from her houſe, poor Jack Rover.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: The generous fellow I ever thought him, and he ſhan't looſe by it—if I could make him believe (aſide)—Well, this is the moſt whimſical affair—you've anticipated me—you'll ſcarce believe that I'm come here purpoſely to paſs myſelf for this young Harry.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: SIR. GEO.
sp.p: Harry, where are you?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I'll try it—my father will be curſedly vext—no matter. (aſide)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Somebody called Harry—zounds, if the real Simon Pure, that is, ſhould be arrived, I'm in a pure way.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Be quiet, that's my confederate, he's to perſonate the father, Sir George, he ſtarted the ſcheme—having heard that an union was intended, and Sir George immediately expected, our plan is, if I can, before his arrival, flouriſh myſelf into the lady's good graces, and whip her up, as ſhe's an heireſs.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: So, you have turn'd fortune hunter. Then 't'was for this plan you parted from me on the road, ſtanding like a figure-poſt, you walk up this way, and I'll walk down this—why, Dick, I did not know you was ſo great a rogue.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: I did not know my fort lay that way, till convinc'd by this experienced ſtranger.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: He muſt be a damn'd impudent old ſcoundrel—who is he, do I know him?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Why, no, I hope not. (aſide)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I'll ſtep down ſtairs, and have the honour of kicking him.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Stop, I wou'd'n't have him hurt, neither.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What's his name?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: His name is Abrawang.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Abrawang, Abrawang—I never heard of him—but, Dick, why did you let him perſuade you into this affair?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Why, faith, I would have been off it, but when once he takes a project into his head, the devil can't drive it out of him.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yes, but the conſtables may drive him into Wincheſter goal.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Your opinion of our intended exploit has made me aſhamed of myſelf—Harkee, Jack, do you puniſh and frighten my adviſer, do you ſtill keep up your character of young 'Squire Thunder—you can eaſily do that, as he, no more than myſelf, has ever ſeen the 'Squire.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: But, by heavens, I'll not be ſuch a damn'd rogue.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, but Jack, if you can marry her, her fortune is a ſnug thing; beſides, if you love each other, I tell you—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Hang her fortune—my love's more noble than the world, prizes not quantity of ditty lands—oh, Dick, ſhe's the moſt lovely—think of her condeſcenſion—why ſhe conſented to play in our play, and you ſhall ſee her, you rogue, you ſhall. Her worth being mounted on the wind, Through all the world bears Roſalind. Exit.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this is the drolleſt adventure—Rover little ſuſpects that I am the identical 'Squire Thunder that he perſonates—I'll lend him my character a little longer—yes this offer is a moſt excellent opportunity of making my poor friend's fortune, without injuring any body. If poſſible, he ſhall have her, I can't regret the loſs of charms I never knew, and for an eſtate, my father is competent to all my wiſhes. Lady Amaranth, by marrying Jack Rover, will gain a man of honour, which, ſhe might looſe in an Earl—it may teaze my father a little at firſt, but he's a good old fellow in the main, and when, I think, he comes to know my motive!—Eh, this muſt be ſhe—an elegant woman, faith—now for a ſpanking lie, to continue her in the belief that Jack is the man ſhe thinks him.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Who art thou, friend?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Madam, I've ſcarce time to warn you againſt the danger you're in, of being impoſed upon by your uncle, Sir George.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p:
He has heard of your Ladyſhip's partiality for his ſon, but is ſo incenſed at the irregularity of his conduct, he intends, if poſſible, to diſinherit him, and to preſent me hither, to paſs me on you for him, deſigning to treat the poor young gentleman
himſelf as an impoſter, in hopes you'll baniſh him from your heart and houſe.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I thank thee, friend, for thy caution—is Sir George ſuch a parent—what's thy name?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Richard Buſkin, Ma'am, the ſtage is my profeſſion—in the 'Squire's late excurſion we contracted an intimacy, and I ſaw ſo many good qualities in him, that I could not think of being the inſtrument of his ruin, nor deprive your Ladyſhip of ſo good a huſband as I am certain he will make you.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Then Sir George intends to diſown him.

sp.speaker: HARRY,
sp.p: Yes Ma'am, I've this moment told the young gentleman of it; he's determined, for a jeſt, to return the compliment, by ſeeming to treat Sir George himſelf as an impoſter.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
