sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, 't'will be a juſt retaliation, and indeed what my uncle deſerveth, for his cruel intentions both to his ſon and me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, has he run away again?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: That's mine uncle.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, here's my father, and my ſtanding out that I'm not his ſon, will raiſe him into the heat of a battle, ha, ha. ha. (aſide) Here he is, Madam, now mind how he'll dub me a 'Squire.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Well, my Lady, was'n't it as my wild rogue ſet you, all tho' calcavell as capers, you've been cutting in the garden. You ſee here I have brought him into line of battle again—you villain, why do you drop a ſtern there, throw a ſalute ſhot, buſs her bob-ſtays, bring to, and come down ſtraight as a maſt, you dog.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Uncle, who is this?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Who is he—egad, that's an odd queſtion, to the fellow that has been cracking your walnuts.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: He's bad at his leſſon.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Certainly, when he ran from ſchool—why don't you ſpeak, you lubber, you are curſed modest—before I came, 'twas all down among the poſies; here, my Lady, take from a father's hand, Harry Thunder.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: That is what I may not.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: There, I thought you would diſguſt her, you flat fiſh.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Here, take from my hand Harry Thunder.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Oh, this is your ſham Sir George,—

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, I've been telling the Lady, and ſtill ſeem to humour him.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: I ſhan't; though how do you Abrawang?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Abrawang!

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: You look like a good actor; aye, that's very well indeed. Never, never looſe ſight of your character; you know Sir George is a noiſy, rurbulent, wicked old knave; bravo! Pout your under lip, purſe your brows:—Very well; but damn it, Abrawang, you ſhould have put a little red on your noſe—mind a rule, never play an old man without a red noſe.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'm in ſuch a fury.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Well we know that.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Some puppy unknown.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: And you don't know this gentleman?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Excellent well! he's a fiſhmonger.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Ah, What▪

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Yes; father and ſon are determin'd not to know each other.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Come, Dick, give the Lady a ſpecimen of your talent Molteys, your only wear, ha, ha, ha, a fool I met, a fool in the foreſt. Here comes Audry.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: La! warrent, what features!

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: 'Sblood! what's this?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A homely thing, Sir, but ſhe's my own.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Your's, you moſt audacious!—What, this ſlut?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I thank the Gods for my ſlutiſhneſs.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: You know this youth.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: My friend, Horatio; I wear him in my heart, yea, in my heart of hearts, as I do this—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Such freedom with my niece, before my face. Do you know that Lady? Do you know my ſon, Sir?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Be quiet; Jaſſier has diſcovered the plot, and you can't decieve the ſenate.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, my conſcience would not let me carry it through.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Aye, his conſcience hanging about the neck of his heart, ſays good Launcelot and good Gobbo, or as aforeſaid good Launcelot Gobbo, take to thy heels and run away.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why, my Lady, explain—ſcoundrel and puppy unknown.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Ma'am, I forgot to tell you our old neighbour Banks and his ſiſter wants you.

sp.speaker: LADY ANN.
sp.p: I come—Uncle, I've heard thy father was kind to thee; return that kindneſs to thy child—if the lamb in wanton play doth fall amongſt the waters, the ſhepherd taketh him out, inſtead of plunging him in deeper till he dieth—though thy hairs now be grey, I'm told once was flaxen; in ſhort, he's too old in folly, who cannot excuſe youth. Exit.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'm an old fool! well, that's damn'd civil of you, Madam Niece; and I'm a grey ſhepherd, with his lambs in the ditch—but as for you, Mr. Goat, I'll—

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: My dear Abrawang, give up the game; her Ladyſhip in ſeeming to take you for her uncle, has been only humming y u—What, the devil, don't you think the divine creature knows her own true-born uncle?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Certainly, to be ſure ſhe knows me.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Will you have done?—Zounds, man, my honoured father was here himſelf this day—her ladyſhip knows his perſon.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Your honoured father, and who the devil's your honour'd ſelf?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Now, by my father's ſon, that's myſelf, it ſhall be ſun, or moon, or Cheſhire-cheeſe—I budge ſtill crop and cropp'd.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What do you bawl out to me about Cheſhire-cheeſe.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: And I ſay, as the ſaying is, your friend has told me all; but to convince you of my forgiveneſs, in our play, as your'e rough and tough, I caſt your character the Wreſtler—I'll do Orlando, kick up your heels before the whole court.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'll—why, dam'me, I'll—and you, you undutiful chick of an old pellican (Lifts up his cane).

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: What are you at here, cudgeling people about?—But, Mr. Buckſkin, I've a word to ſay to you in private.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Buckſkin, take that (ſtrikes him).

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Why, dam'me, Mr. Abrawang, you're a moſt obſtinate drum, and very—

div.stage: Enter LAMP, TRAP, JANE, and SERVANT MAID.

sp.speaker: LAMP.
sp.p: All the world's a ſtage, and all men and women—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: The men are rogues, and the women huſſies. (Beats them off, and ſtrikes Rover).

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: A blow, Eſſex, a blow, an old raſcally impoſter; ſtigmatize me with a blow—I muſt not put up with it.—Z • unds! I ſhall be tweak'd by the noſe all round the country. If I can get the country lad to ſteal me a pair of piſtols, ſtrike me, ſo may this arm daſh him to the earth like a dead dog, deſpiſe, pride, ſhame, and the name of villain light on me, if I don't bring you Mr. Abrawang,

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Madam, I would have paid the rent of my little cottage; but dare ſay it was without your Ladyſhip's conſent that your Steward has turned me • ut and pu • my neighbour in poſſeſion.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: My Steward oppreſs the poor! I did not know it indeed.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: The pangs of adverſity I could bear; but the innocent partner of my misfortunes, my unhappy ſiſter—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I did deſire Ephraim to ſend for thy ſiſter; did ſhe dwell with thee, and both now without a home? let her come to mine.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: The hand of miſery hath ſtruck me beneath your notice.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thou doſt miſtake; to need my aſſiſtance is the higheſt claim to my attention—let me ſee her. (Exit Banks.) I could chide myſelf that theſe paſttimes have turned mine eyes from the houſe of woe. Ah, think ye proud and happy a •• luent, how many in your dancing moments pine in want, drink the ſalt tears—their morſel the bread of miſery, and ſhrinking from the cold blaſt into their cheerleſs hovels!

div.p: Thou art welcome: I feel myſelf intereſted in thy concern.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I judge thou wert not always unhappy, tell me thy condition, then I ſhall better know how to ſerve thee; is thy brother thy ſole kindred?

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I had a huſband and a ſon.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Widow, if it is real, not images, thou wouldeſt forget—impart to me thy ſtory, 'tis rumour'd in the village thy brother was a clergyman, tell me.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Madam, he was; but he has loſt his early patron, and he's now poor and unbeneſiced.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: But thy huſband.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: By this brother's advice (now twenty years ſince) I was prevailed on to liſten to the addreſſes of a young ſea officer, for my brother had been chaplain in the navy; but, to our ſurprize and mortification, we diſcovered, by the honeſty of a ſailor, in whom we put confidence, that the Captain's deſign was only to decoy me into a ſeeming marriage; our humble friend intreated of us to put the deceit on his maſter, by concealing from him that my brother was not in orders; he, flattered with the hopes of procuring me an eſtabliſhment, gave into ſuppoſed impoſition, and performed the ceremony.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Duplicity, even with a good intent, is ill.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam, the event has juſtified your confuse, for my huſband, not knowing himſelf really bound by any legal tie, abandoned me—I followed him to the Indies; diſtracted, till ſeeing him. I left my infant at one of our ſettlements; but, after a fruitleſs ſearch, on my return, I found the friend, to whoſe care I committed my child, was compelled to retire from the ravages of war, but where I could not hear—rent with agonizing pangs, without a child or huſband, I again ſaw England, and my brother, who wounded himſelf with remorſe for being the cauſe of my misfortunes, ſecluded himſelf from all joys of ſocial life, and invited me to partake the comfort of ſolitude in that aſylum, from whence we have both juſt now been driven.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: My pity can do thee no good, yet muſt I pity thee; but reſignation to what muſt be, may reſtore peace; if my means can procure thee comfort, they are at thy pleaſure—come let thy griefs ſubſide—inſtead of thy cottage, accept thou and thy brother every convenience that my manſion can afford.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Madam, I can only thank you with (weeps).

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: My thanks are here—come thou ſhalt be chearful—I will introduce thee to my ſprightly couſin! Harry, and his father, my humourous uncle—we have delights going forward that may amuſe thee.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Kind Lady.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Come, uncle, though a quaker, thou ſee'ſt I'm merry—the ſweeteſt joy of wealth and power is to cheer one another's drooping heart, and wipe from the pallid cheek the tear of ſorrow.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter three Men, dreſſed as Sailors.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAILOR.
sp.p: WELL, lads, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: We've long been upon our ſhifts, and after all our tricks, twiſts, and turns, as London was too hot for us, a trip to Portſmouth was a hit.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Aye, but ſince the caſh we touched upon pretending to be able bodied ſeamen is now come to the laſt ſhilling, and as we deſerted, means of freſh ſupply muſt be thought on to take us to London.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: Aye, now to recruit the pocket, without hazarding the neck.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: By an advertiſement poſted on the ſtocks yonder, there are collectors on this road, thirty guineas offered by the quaker lady, owner of the eſtates round here—I wiſh we could knap any ſtraggler to bring before her, a quaker will only require yea for an oath, we might pick up this thirty guineas.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: Yes, but we muſt take care, if we fall into the hands of this gentleman that's in purſuit of us—'Sdeath, is not that his man, the old boatſwain?

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Don't run, I think we three are a match for him.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: Let's keep up our characters of ſailors, we may get ſomething out of him; a pityful ſtory makes ſuch an impreſſion on the ſoft heart of a true tar, that he'll open his hard hand and drop you his laſt guinea—if we can but make him believe we were preſſed, we have him, only mind me.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: To rattle my lanthorn, Sir George's temper now always blows a hurricane.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: What cheer?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Ha, boy.

sp.speaker: 1ſt SAIL.
sp.p: Bob up with your ſpeaking trumpet.

sp.speaker: 2nd SAIL.
sp.p: D'ye ſee, brother, this is the thing—

div.p: We three hands, juſt come home after a long voyage, were preſſed in the river, and without letting us ſee our friends brought round to Portſmouth, and then we entered freely—'cauſe why, we had no choice—then we run—we hear ſome gentleman's in chace of us, and as the ſhots are all out, we'll ſurrender.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Surrender—then you have no ſhots left, indeed—let's ſee (feeling his pocket) I hav'n't the loading of a gun about me now, and this ſame Monſieur Poverty is a bitter enemy.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: 'Tis the deſerters I'm after.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Meet me in an hour's time in the little wood yonder, I'll raiſe the wind to blow you into a ſafe latitude—Keep out to ſea, my maſter's the rock you'll certainly ſplit upon.

sp.speaker: 2d SAIL.
sp.p: This is the firſt time we ever ſaw you, but we'll ſteer by your chart, for I never knew one ſeaman betray another. Exeunt Men.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Then they have been preſſed—I can't blame them ſo much for running away.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir George would certainly hang them.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: You lie; they ſhall eat beef and drink the King's health—run and tell them ſo—ſtop, I'll tell them myſelf.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Now you are yourſelf, and a kind gentleman, as you uſed to be.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Since theſe idle rogues are inclined to return to their duty, they ſhan't want ſea ſtores; take this money—but I'll meet them myſelf, and adviſe them as I would my own children. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p:
Which way did this Mr. Abrawang take? —Dick Buſkin, I think, has no ſuſpicion of my intention, and ſince Sim has, without making an alarm, procured theſe piſtols, ſuch a cholerick ſpark will
fight, I dare ſay. If I fall, or even ſurvive this affair, I'll leave the field of love and the fair prize to the young gentleman I've perſonated, for I'm determined to ſee Lady Amaranth no more—Oh, here comes Abrawang.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Now to relieve theſe ſea gulls—they muſt be hovering about this place—Ha, puppy unknown.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You're the very man I was ſeeking for—you're not ignorant. Mr. Abrawang?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Mr. What?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: You'd not reſign your title—oh, very well, I'll indulge you—Sir George Thunder, you honoured me with a blow.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Did'n't hurt you.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Sir, but let me proceed like a gentleman; as it's my pride to reject even favours, no man ſhall offer me an injury.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: In rank we're equal.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Are we, faith—the Engliſh of all this is, we're to fight.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Sir, you have mark'd in me an indelible ſtain, only to be waſh'd out by my blood.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why, I've only one objection to fighting you.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: That you're too brave a lad to be kill'd.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Brave, no, Sir, at preſent I wear the ſtigma of a coward.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Zounds, I like a bit of fighting—hav'nt had a morſel a long time—don't know when I ſmelt gunpowder, but to bringdown a woodcock.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Take your ground.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I'm ready—but are we to thruſt with bull-ruſhes, like two frogs, or like two ſquirrels, pelt one another with nut-ſhells, for I don't ſee any other weapons here.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Sir, here are the weapons.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Well, this is bold work for a privateer to give battle to a King's ſhip.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Try your charge, Sir, and take your ground.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: I wou'd'n't wiſh to ſink, burn, or deſtroy what I thought was built for good ſervice, but dam'me if I don't bring wing to you, to teach you better manners, ſo take care, or I'll put ſome red on your noſe.
sp.stage: Enter three Men, without ſeeing Rover.
sp.p: 1ſt SAIL. Ah, here's the honeſt fellow has brought us ſome caſh.

sp.speaker: 2nd SAIL.
sp.p: We're betray'd, it's the very gentleman that's in purſuit of us, and this promiſe was only a decoy to throw us into his power—the piſtol! (aſide)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Good charge (trying the charge, the men ruſh forward, and one of them ſmacks the piſtol from him.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Ha, boys.

sp.speaker: 2nd SAIL.
sp.p: You'd have our lives, and we'll have yours. (Rover runs to his aſſiſtance, and knocks the piſtol out of his hand—they run off.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Raſcals! (purſues them.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: My brave lad, I'll— (going.)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, you ſhan't. (ſtops him.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: The rogues will.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Never mind the rogues. (a piſtol fired without.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: S'blood, muſt I ſee my preſerver periſh? (ſtruggling.)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I'm your preſerver, and I will periſh, but I'll bring you out of harm's way.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Tho' he'd fight me himſelf—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: We all know you'd fight the very devil.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: He ſav'd my life.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I'll ſave your life— (whips him up)—hawl up, my noble little jolly-boat.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Boy, go on with the inventory.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: How unlucky, feyther, to lay hold on me, when I wanted to practice my part.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: This proceeding is too ſevere—to lay an execution on my wretched trifling goods, when I thought—

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: Aye, you've gone up to the big houſe with your complaint—her Ladyſhip's ſteward, to be ſure, has made me give back your cottage and farm, but your goods I ſeized for my rent.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Leave me but a few neceſſaries, by my own labour, and the goodneſs of my neighbours, I may ſoon redeem what the law has put in your hands.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: The affair is now in my lawyer's hands, and plaintiff and defendant chattering about it is all ſmoke.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Feyther, don't be ſo cruel to Mr. Banks.

sp.speaker: GAM.
sp.p: I'll mark what I may want for myſelf—ſtay you and ſee that not a pin's point be removed.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: Dam'me, if I'll be a watch dog to bite the poor, that I won't, Mr. Banks, as my feyther intends to put up your goods to auction, if you could but get a friend to buy the choice of them for you again; ſiſter Jane has got ſteward to advance her a quarter's wages, and when I've gone to fell corn for feyther, I've made a market penny now and then—it is'n't much, but every little helps. (offers a leather purſe.)

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: I thank you, my good natured boy, but keep your money.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: I remember, about eight years ago you ſav'd me from being drown'd at Black Poole—if you'll not take this I'll fling it into Black Poole directly.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: My kind lad, I'll not hurt your feelings, by oppoſing your liberality. (takes the purſe)

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: He, he, he!—He's given my heart ſuch pleaſure, as I never felt, nor I'm ſure my feyther before me.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: But, Sim, whatever may be his opinion of worldly prudence, ſtill remember he's your parent.

sp.speaker: SIM.
sp.p: I will—One elbow chair, one claw table. (crying out.)

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: The confuſion into which Lady Amaranth's family is thrown, by the ſudden departure and apprehended danger of her young couſin, muſt have prevented her Ladyſhip from giving that attention to our affairs that I'm ſure was her inclination—If I can but prevail on my brother to accept of her protection—Heavens, what's this?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What a race—I've got clear of thoſe blood-hounds at laſt; if Abrawang had but followed and back'd me, we'd have tickled their cataſ • rop, but three to one is odds, ſo ſafe's the word. Who's houſe is this I've run into—the friendly cottage of my hoſpitable old gentleman—are you at home? (calls) I had a hard ſtruggle for it, murder was certainly their intent—it was well for me I was born without brains—I'm quite weak and faint.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Sir, a'n't you well?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam, I aſk your pardonſyes, Madam, very well, I thank you, now exceedingly well—got into a kind of rumpus with ſome worthy gentlemen—not gentlemen, but ſimple farmers, who miſtook me, I fancy, for a ſheath of barley, for they had me down, and their flails flew merrily about my ears, but I got up, and when I could no longer fight like a maſtiff, I run like a greyhound—but, dear Madam, pray excuſe me—this is very rude, faith.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: You ſeem diſturb'd, will you take any refreſhment?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam, you're very good—only a glaſs of ſome currant wine, if you pleaſe; I think it ſtands ſomewhere thereabouts. (Ame. fetches a Bottle and glaſs.) Madam, I've the honour of drinking your health.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I hope you're not hurt, Sir.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: A little better, but very faint ſtill, I had a ſample of this before, and lik'd it ſo much that Ma'am won't you take another? (ſhe declines.) Ma'am if you'd been fighting as I have, you'd be glad of a drop (drinks again.) Now I'm as well as any man in Illyria—got a few hard knocks tho'.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: You'd better repoſe a little, you ſeem'd much diſordered coming in.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Why Madam you muſt know that it was.—

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Come Ma'am, Mr. Gammon wants this chair to make up the half dozen above.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: What's all this?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Why, the furniture's ſeiz'd on execution, and a man muſt do his duty.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Then ſcoundrel know, that a man's firſt duty is civility and tenderneſs to a woman.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Heaven's where's my brother, this gentleman will bring himſelf into trouble.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Maſter d'ye ſee I'm repreſentative for his honour the High Sheriff.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Every High Sheriff ſhould be a gentleman, and when he's repreſented by a raſcal he's diſhonoured; damn it, I might as well live about Covert Garden and every night get beating the watch, for here among groves and meadows, I'm always ſquabling with conſtables.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Come, come, I muſt. (ſits down.)

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: As you ſay Sir, laſt Wedneſday, ſo it was, Sir, your moſt obedient humble ſervant, pray Sir have you ever been aſtoniſhed?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Becauſe Sir, I intend to aſtoniſh you, (Takes a ſtick off a table and beats him.) Now Sir, are you aſtoniſhed?

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: Yes, but ſee if I dont ſuit you with an action.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p:
Right—ſuit the action to the word and the word to the action. See if the gentleman be not affrighted,
damme, but I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: A fine example when goods are ſeized by the law.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Thou worm and maggot of the law, hop me over every kennel houſe, or you ſhall hop without my cuſtom.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: I dont value your cuſtom.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I have aſtoniſh'd, now I'll amaze you.

sp.speaker: OFF.
sp.p: No Sir, I won't be amazed, but ſee if I dont.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Hop. Madam, theſe ſort of gentry are but bad company for a lady, ſo I'll juſt ſee him to the door—Ma'am I'm your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I feel a ſtrange kind of curioſity to know who this young gentleman is. I find my heart intereſted, I can't account for it; he must know the houſe by the freedom he took: but then his gaity, (without familiar rudeneſs) elegance of manners and good breeding, ſeem to make him at home every where—my brother I think muſt know him.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Amelia did you ſee the young gentleman that was here, ſome ruſſians have bound and dragg'd him from the door on the allegation of three men who means to ſwear he has robbed them, and have taken him to Lady Amaranth's.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: How! he did enter in confuſion as if purſued, but I'll ſtake my life on his innocence. I'll ſpeak to her Ladyſhip, and in ſpite of calumny he ſhall have juſtice; he wou'd'n't let me be inſulted, becauſe he ſaw me an unprotected woman, without a huſband or a ſon, and ſhall he want an advocate brother? come—

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p:
I believe there is no ſoul in the houſe but myſelf, my Lady has all the folks round the country, so ſeareh after the young 'Squire; ſhe'll certainly break her heart if any thing happens to him. I don't
wonder, for ſure he's a dear •• cet gentleman. His going has ſpoiled our play, and I had almoſt got my part by h •• rt, but muſt, muſt go and do up the room for Mr. Banks's ſiſter, whom my Lady has invited here—

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: The man John Dory hath carried the man George here in his arms and he locked him up; coming in they did look like a blue lobſter with a ſhrimp in its claw. Here is the damſal I love alone.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: They ſay when folks look in the glaſs, they ſee the black gentleman, [Loves in a glaſs,] La, there he is!

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thou art employed in vanity.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Well, who are you?

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: It's natural for woman to love man.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Yea, but not ſuch ugly men as you are, why did you come in to frigh'en me? when you know there's nobody here but ourſelves?

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I'm glad of that; I'm the elm, and thou'rt the honey-ſuckle, let thine arms entwine me.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: What a rougue is here, but yonder comes my Lady. I ſhew him off in his true colours. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Claſp me round.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I will if you will pull off your hat and make me a low bow.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I cannot bend my knee, nor take off my beaver.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Then you're very impudent, go along.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: To win thy ſavour, (moves his hat.)

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Well now read me aſpeech out of that fine play book.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Read a play book! abo-mi-na-tion! but wilt thou kiſs me?

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: I kiſs a man, abomination, but you may take my ha d.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Ch, 'its a comfort to the lip of the faithful.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: How! (taps him on the ſhoulder.) Ah, thou ſly and deceitful hypocrite!

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Verily Mary I was buffotted by Satan in the ſhape of a damſal

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: My ſpirit is ſad tho' I move ſo nimbly.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: But oh, heaven's no tiding of my deareſt Harry. Jane let them renew their ſearch.

sp.speaker: JANE.
sp.p: Here's Madam Amelia—but I'll make brother Sim look for the young 'Squire.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Oh, Madam might I implore your influence with—

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Thou art I'll accommodated here, but I hope thou wilt excuſe it, my mind is a ſea of trouble, my peace is ſhipwrecked. Oh, had'ſt thou ſeen my Couſin Harry! all who know him muſt be anxious for his ſafety! how unlucky, this ſervant to prevent Sir George from giving him that aſſiſtance, which paternal cares and indeed gratitude demanded, for 'twas filial affection had him to purſue thoſe wicked men, callous to every feeling of humanity—they may—yes, my Henry in the opening bud of manlineſs is nipp'd!

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Heave a-head.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Raſcal, whip me up like a pound of tea, dance about like a young bear! make me quit the preſerver of my life, yes, puppy unknown will think me a paltroon, and that I was afraid to follow and ſecond him.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You may as well turn into your hamock, for out to night you ſhall not go. (See's Amelia Mercy of heaven is'n't it—only look.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: 'Tis my Amelia.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Reef your foreſail firſt, you crack'd her heart by ſheering off, and now you'll overſet her by bringing too.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Are you at length return'd to me, my Seymour?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Seymour!—her mind's diſturbed—this is mine uncle, Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: No, no, my Lady, ſhe knows what ſhe's ſaying, well enough.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Niece, I have been a villain to this lady, I confeſs but, my dear Amelia, providence has done you juſtice in part, for from the firſt month I quitted you, I have never entered one happy hour on my journals—hearing that you foundered, and conſidering myſelf the cauſe, the worm of remorſe has knaw'd my timbers.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: You're not ſtill offended with me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Me—can you forgive me my offence, and condeſcend to take my hand as an atonement?

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Your hand—do you forget we're already • arried?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Aye, there was my raſcality.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: You may ſay that.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: That marriage, my dear, I'm aſhamed to own it—but it was—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: As good as if done by the Chaplain of the Eagle.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, you impudent crimp, you pander, you bad adviſer—I'll ſtrike my falſe colours, I'll acknowledge the chaplain you provided was—

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: A good man, and a greater honour to his black, than your honour has been to your blue cloth; by the word of a ſeaman, here he is himſelf.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Your brother!

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Capt. Seymour! have I found you, Sir.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: My dear Banks, I'll make every reparation—Amelia ſhall really be my wife.

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: That Sir, my ſiſter is already, for when I performed the marriage ceremony, which you took only as a cloak of your deception, I was actually in orders.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Now who's the crimp and the pander?—I never told you this, becauſe I thought a man's own reflections were the beſt puniſhment for betraying an innocent woman.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: You ſhall be a Poſt Captain for this, ſink me, if you ſhan't.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Madam, my inmoſt ſoul partaketh of thy gladneſs and joy for thy reformation; (to Sir Geo.) but thy prior marriage to this lady annuls the ſubſequent, and my couſin Harry is not now thy heir.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: So much the better, he's an unnatural cub—but, Amelia, I flatter myſelf I have an heir—my infant boy.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Ha, huſband, you had, but—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Gone—well, well, I ſee I have been a miſerable ſcoundrel—I'll adopt that brave kind lad, that wou'd'n't let any body •• ll me but himſelf, he ſhall have my eſtate, that's my own acquiſition—my lady marrying him— 〈…〉 Unknown's a fine fellow! Amelia, only for him you'd never have found your huſband.—Captain Seymour is Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: BANKS.
sp.p: Are you Sir George Thunder?

sp.speaker: LAND.
sp.p: Pleaſe you, Madam, they have got a foot-pad in cuſtody.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I'm come to ſit in judgment, for there is a bad man in thy houſe, Mary—bring him before me.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Before you, old Squintabus; perhaps you don't know I'm a magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I ll examine him.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: You be damn'd, I'll examine him myſelf—tow him in here, I'll give him a paſſport to Wincheſter bilbow.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir, as you hope for mercy, extend it to this youth, and even ſhould he be guilty, which from our knowledge of his benevolent and noble nature, I think next to an impoſſibility, let the ſervices he has rendered us plead for
him—he protected your forſaken wife, and her unhappy brother, in the hour of want and ſorrow.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, Amelia plead for a robber!—conſider, my love, Juſtice is above bias or partiality; if my ſon violated the laws of his country, l'd deliver him up as a public victim to diſgrace and puniſhment.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Oh, my impartial uncle! Had thy country any laws to puniſh him, who inſtead of paltry gold, would rob the artleſs virgin of her deareſt treaſure, in the rigid judge I ſhould now behold the trembling criminal.

div.stage: Enter TWITCH, with two men, and ROVER bound.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Speak thou.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Hold thy clapper, thou—you wretched perſon, who are the proſecutors.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Call in.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Will nobody ſtop his mouth (John carries him up the ſtage.) Where are the proſecutors?

sp.speaker: TWITCH.
sp.p: There, tell his worſhip the juſtice.

sp.speaker: 1ſt MAN.
sp.p: A juſtice—oh, the devil!—I thought we ſhould have nothing but quakers to deal with (aſide)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Come, how did this fellow rob you?

sp.speaker: 1ſt MAN.
sp.p: Why, your honour, I ſwear—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Oh, ho!

sp.speaker: 1ſt MAN.
sp.p: Zounds, we're in the wrong, this is the very—

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Clap down the hatches, ſecure theſe ſharks.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I'm glad to find you here, Abrawang, as I believe you have ſome knowledge of theſe gentlemen.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Heaven's, my Couſin Harry!

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: The Devil! is'n't that my ſpear and ſhield?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: My young maſter, what have you been at here, (unbinds him,) this r • pe may be wanted yet.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: My dear fellow are you ſafe?

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Yes, Dick, I was brought here very ſafe, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: A confederate in cuſtody has made a conſeſſion of their villainy, that they concerted this plan to accuſe him of a robbery, firſt for revenge, then in hopes to ſhare the reward for apprehending him; he alſo owns they are not ſailors but depredators on the public.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: What, could you find no jacket to diſgrace by your wearing than that of an Engliſh ſeaman, a character, whoſe bravery is even the admiration of his enemies, and genuine honeſty of heart, the glory of human nature? Keep them ſafe.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Aye, I knew the rope would be wanted,

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Not knowing that the Juſtice of Peace whom they brought the lad before, is the very man they attacked, ha, ha, ha! the rogues have fallen into their own ſnare.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: What now you're a Juſtice of Peace—well ſaid, Abrawang.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Then, Sir George, you know him too?

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Know him, to be ſure I do.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Still, Sir George—what then you will not reſign your Knighthood! Madam, I'm happy to ſee you again. Ah, how do you do, my kind hoſt? (to Banks)

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: I rejoice at thy ſafety, be reconcil'd to him. (To Sir George.)

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Reconcil'd, if I don't love, reſpect and honour him, I ſhould be unworthy of the life he reſcued—but who is he?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Sir, he is—

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p: Dick, I thank you for your good wiſhes, but I'm ſtill determin'd not to impoſe on this Lady. Madam, as I firſt told that well-meaning tar, when he forc'd me to your houſe, I'm not the ſon of Sir George Thunder.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Then I wiſh you was the ſon of an Admiral, and I your father.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: You refuſe the lady—to puniſh you, I have a mind to take her myſelf my dear Couſin.

sp.speaker: ROVER.
sp.p:
Stop Dick, if I who adore her won't, you
ſhall not no, no. Madam, never mind what the fellow ſays, he's as poor as myſelf, is'n't he, Abrawang?

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Then, my dear Rover, ſince you are ſo obſtinately intereſted, I'll no longer • eize my father, whom you here ſee, and in your ſtrolling friend, his very truant Harry that ran from Portſmouth Academy, and joined you and fellow Comedians.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Dear Couſin forgive me, if thro' my zeal for the happineſs of my friend, I endeavoured to promote your's, by giving you a huſband, more worthy than myſelf.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Am I to believe, Madam, is your uncle Sir George Thunder in the room?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: 'Tis you in reality, what I've had the impudence to aſſume, and have perplex'd your father with ray ridiculous effrontery. I told you, (to John) I was not the perſon you took me for, but you muſt bring your damn'd Chariot—I am aſham'd and mortiſed—Madam, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: Thou art welcome to go.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Sir George, as the father of my friend, I cannot lift my hand againſt you, but I hope, Sir, you'll apologize to me apart.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Aye, with pleaſure, my noble ſplinter. Now tell me from what dock you were launched, my heart of oak?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: I heard in England, Sir, but from my earlieſt knowledge, till within a few years I've been in the Eaſt Indies.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Beyond ſeas—well, and how?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: It ſeems I was committed an infant to the care of a lady, who was herſelf obliged by the gentle Hyder Ally to ſtrike her toilet, and decamp without beat of drumb, leaving me a chubby little fellow, ſquatted on a carpet; a ſerjeant's wife alone returned, and ſnatched me off triumphant, thro' fire, ſmoke, cannon, cries, and carnage.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Doſt thou mark?

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Sir, can you recollect the name of the town where—

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, the town, was Negapatnam.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: An officer, who had much rather act Hot-ſpur on the ſtage than in the field, brought me up belind the ſcenes at the Calcutta theatre, I was enroll'd on the boards, acted myſelf into favour of a colonel, promiſed a pair of colours, but impatient to find my parents, hid myſelf in the ſteerage of a homewardbound ſhip, aſſumed the name of Rover, from the uncertainty of my fate, and having murdered more Poets than Rajars, ſtepped on Engliſh ground unincumbered with rupees or pagodas.—Ha, ha, ha, would'ſt thou have come home ſo, little Ephraim?

sp.speaker: EPH.
sp.p: I would bring myſelf home with ſome money.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Excuſe my curioſity, Sir—what was the lady's name in whoſe care you were left?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, ſhe was the lady of a Major Linſtock, but I heard my mother's name was Seymour.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: Why, Amelia!

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: My ſon!

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: It is my Charles. (embraces him).

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Tol de lol!— (dances a hornpipe ſtep)—Tho' I never heard it before, my heart told me he was a chip of the old block. Your father, (to Rover, and points to Sir Geo.)

sp.speaker: Rov.
sp.p: Can it—

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Yes, my ſon, Sir George Thunder here is Captain Seymour, in ſearch of whom you may have heard I quitted England.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Heavens, then have I attempted to raiſe my hands againſt a parent's life.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: My brave boy—then have I a ſon with ſpirit to fight me as a ſailor, yet defend me as a father.

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Uncle, you'll recollect 'twas I friſt introduced this ſon to thee.

sp.speaker: SIR GEO.
sp.p: And I hope you'll next introduce a grandſon to me, young Slyboots.—Harry, you have loſt your fortune.

sp.speaker: HARRY.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—but I've gained a brother, whoſe friendſhip, before I knew him to be ſuch, I prized before the firſt fortune in England.

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: My deareſt Roſalind.

sp.speaker: AME.
sp.p: Then, will you take our Charles?

sp.speaker: LADY A.
sp.p: Yea; but only on conditions, thou beſtoweſt thy fortune on his friend and brother—mine is ſufficient for us both, is it not?

sp.speaker: ROV.
sp.p: Angelic creature! to think of my generous friend. But now for As You Like It; where's Lamp and Trap. I ſhall ever love a play, a ſpark from Shakeſpeare's muſe of fire was the ſtar that guided me through my deſolate and bewildered maze of life, and brought me to theſe unexpected bleſſings.
sp.l: To merit friends ſo good, ſo ſweet a wife,
The tender huſband be my part for life.
My Wild Oats ſown, let candid Theſpian laws
